subtasks: Identify female livestock in heat
Check females for signs of pregnancy
Administer hormones or other substances to promote estrus
Monitor livestock for signs of estrus
Perform artificial insemination on female livestock
Maintain records of breeding activities
Clean and disinfect breeding facilities
Prepare stalls or pens for breeding
Check equipment (e.g., insemination guns, palpation tools) for functionality

tasks.task: Monitoring and care of breeding animals
subtasks: Provide nutrition and care for breeding females
Check females for signs of illness or discomfort
Separate problem animals from the breeding group if necessary
Handle and restrain male livestock during breeding
Ensure males are in good health and fertile
Identify top breeding males for use
Keep records on pedigree and performance of breeding animals
Observe and record estrus behavior in females
Perform physical examination to confirm estrus
Record details of each insemination (date, time, male used)
Note the response of females to treatments
Update records of animals that are pregnant or not
If no conception occurs, adjust protocols (e.g., timing, hormones)
Provide good living conditions for breeding animals
Monitor for stress or signs of discomfort related to estrus induction
Provide pain relief or treatment if necessary
Properly collect semen from males
Store semen at appropriate conditions until use
Administer semen into the reproductive tract of the female correctly
Follow proper protocols for insemination fluid and temperature
Check males and females regularly for diseases that affect fertility
Treat or cull as needed
Document the duration and intensity of estrus
Look for multiple estrus cycles in females
Check palpation equipment for functionality
Administer progestins to synchronize estrus
Withdraw progestins to induce estrus
Palpate the reproductive organs to check for corpus luteum and ovary configuration
Adjust feeding according to reproductive needs
Keep records of pregnancies, their outcomes, and the offspring
Confirm proper depth and angle of insemination for successful conception
Ensure the semen is deposited at the appropriate site
Use estrus detectors (e.g., heat detectors) as needed in addition to physical examination
Plan breeding cycles to maximize conception rates
Identify females that do not become pregnant and plan their management (e.g., raising for another purpose)
Seek advice from veterinarians on infertility issues in the herd
Watch for behavioral signs of estrus (e.g., restlessness, increased vocalization)
